blueberries.name: Blueberries
blueberries.summary: NLCD Class 52:  Areas dominated by woody shrubs or small trees less than 5 meters tall with shrub canopy typically greater than 20% of total vegetation. This class includes true shrubs, young trees in an early successional stage or trees stunted from environmental conditions. Examples include chaparral, scrub oak woodland, subalpine krumholz forests, sagebrush steppe, and desert scrublands.

sweet_potatoes.name: Sweet Potatoes
sweet_potatoes.summary: NLCD Class 31:  Areas of bedrock, desert pavement, scarps, talus, slides, volcanic material, glacial debris, sand dunes, strip mines, gravel pits and other accumulations of earthen material. Generally, vegetation accounts for less than 15% of total cover.

oranges.name: Oranges
oranges.summary: NLCD Classes 41, 42, and 43:  Areas dominated by trees generally greater than 5 meters tall and greater than 20% of total vegetation cover.  This includes deciduous, evergreen and mixed forests.

almonds.name: Almonds
almonds.summary: NLCD Class 71:  Areas dominated by grass or herbaceous vegetation, generally greater than 80% of total vegetation. These areas are not subject to intensive management such as tilling, but can be utilized for grazing.  Examples include oak savanna, longleaf pine savanna, and tall and shortgrass prairies.

wildflower_strip.name: Wildflower Strip
wildflower_strip.summary: Grouping of residential homes on a development site in order to use the extra land as open space, recreation or agriculture.

bee_hab_a.name: Bee Habitat A
bee_hab_a.summary: A roof of a building that is partially or completely covered with vegetation and a growing medium, planted over a waterproofing membrane.

bee_hab_b.name: Bee Habitat B
bee_hab_b.summary: A roof of a building that is partially or completely covered with vegetation and a growing medium, planted over a waterproofing membrane.
